awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Minimally Invasive Articulating Intubation Stylet
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project is that it provides a critical advancement in intubation devices and procedures, performed in both planned surgeries and in emergency procedures. The benefits from the technology apply to 25 – 30 million annual planned and emergency intubations performed each year in the USA alone. The technology advanced in this project will improve at least 10% of all intubation procedures. The proposed end-product is low-cost, disposable, and requires limited training. facilitating adoption. The technology aims to greatly reduce the incidence of patient injuries, primarily due to loss of airway. These improved outcomes are important to the clinics performing these procedures. 

This Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project seeks to validate and further refine the design of a new medical device featuring significant articulation of a stylet/introducer. The device can quickly and intuitively maneuver through complex anatomy into a patient’s trachea. The device design utilizes high-precision, micro-components in a very small mechanism such that a small-diameter endotracheal tube may pass over the device to be secured in the patient’s trachea. This mechanism aims to reduce the total time needed for successful intubation, to increase the rate of success on first-time attempts, to reduce incidents of loss of oxygen, to assist in intubation in emergency settings, and generally to reduce procedural injuries to patients. The project will entail creating a significant number of production-quality devices for mannequin testing. The simulation will measure reductions in procedure time and inform the design for clinical use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the Minimally Invasive Articulating Intubations Stylet program was to develop and prove the capability of a device that would improve the outcomes of intubations when faced with a challenging airway (~10% of all intubations) for both patients and clinicians.  The program aimed to accomplish this goal by designing and building a device that was low-cost, disposable, had capabilities to navigate difficult airways and required limited training and to test this capability via an efficacy study of the device against the current standard of care. These measurable outcomes can be directly correlate to other measures that increase risk for the patient including number of attempts (the greater the number of attempts the higher the risk to the patient) and the time to intubate (also the longer it takes to complete the intubations the lower the patient’s oxygen saturation and the higher the risk of oxygen related harms).

            The design and manufacturer of the device was successful as devices were able to be built and tested in a lab setting to verify they met the design specifications. This included design and manufacture of tools and development of a manufacturing process capable of building the quantity of devices needed for testing and to support the efficacy study. The efficacy study was developed in collaboration with an educational facility and targeted the following key outcomes: time and number of attempts to navigate into the trachea, time to complete the full intubation procedure and included a post study survey of the clinicians to understand stress of the procedure and control the clinician had using the various tools. To be able to accurately assess the capability and impact of the devices a high-fidelity difficult airway mannequin had to be developed, as current difficult airway mannequins did not provide an adequate representation of difficult airways faced in a clinical setting. The efficacy study was completed with a sufficient number of participants to ensure statistically significant findings and in all measures the Minimally Invasive Articulating Intubations Stylet was superior to the current standard of care. These results are significant for the clinicians, the patients and the anesthesia community as safely and quickly intubating patients is essential to be able to provide patients the procedures they need.

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2023
Modified by: Benn Horrisberger
